results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: Circus
results.brief_description: Documentary about life on the road with the Swiss Circus Royale as it tours outback Australia. Intercuts performance scenes with shots of the less glamorous aspects of circus life. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Witness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Through intermingling static images of a playground, the beach and the town, David Greig paints a picture of Apollo Bay, on the west coast of Victoria, that is evocative and nostalgic.

results.title: The Bass Valley Community Centre
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Clare Le Serve started a craft group for young mums in the early 1980s, she could not have imagined that it would grow over the next 30 years to become such an amazing community asset. With the help of local volunteers and paid staff, the Community Centre offers essential services that make a positive impact on the people of Bass and the surrounding Waterline region in south-eastern Victoria.

results.title: Moon to Dust
results.creator_credit: Kanlaya Padungsin and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description: Winner of ‘Best Character Animation’ for RMIT’s AIM Graduate Screenings, 2009. Set to the song of the same name by Georgia Fields, ‘Moon to Dust’ is a beautiful and melancholic rendering of belonging, isolation and change.

results.title: The Pyre of Triune
results.brief_description:
A paint-on-glass animation exploring personal themes of spirituality - representing a journey into the soul and the discovery of the spirit of god, a struggle for meaning and the light within.
Created as part of coursework at the Centre for Animation and Interactive Media (AIM), RMIT, 1997.

results.title: The Very last thing from Pandora's Box
results.brief_description:
Beautifully drawn and coloured animation ponders human existence - the misery and fleetingness of life and its solace, hope.
This work was produced as part of AIM (Centre for Animation and interactive Media), RMIT, 2003.

results.title: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and ACMI

video_links.name: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward

results.brief_description:
Neal Benezra, director of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA), talks about the history of the institution with regards to its upcoming expansion. Benezra tells the story of his journey to find the architects who designed the expansion and explains the thinking behind the vision for the building.

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.

results.title: Fire and water
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description:
Roxby Downs, in South Australia and run by Western Mining (later BHP Billiton), is the world’s largest uranium mine. It also sits on sacred Aboriginal land and proposals to increase production were considered to have possibly severe implications. The population and culture of the Arabunna and Koktha people could be effected, as could environmental and ecological concerns such as local water levels and quality.

In September 1997, the music festival ‘Roxstop’ was held to prevent these developments to the mine. In amongst the protests and celebrations, activists went on a company-hosted tour of the mine to learn how Western Mining justify their position on expanding operations.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
